item.title: How To Watch the 2025 Phoenix Mercury Season
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Finn
item.description:
The Phoenix Mercury’s gritty return to playoff contention in 2024 has fans buzzing for the 2025 season. Here’s how you can watch every game as they look to make an even deeper run.

The post How To Watch the 2025 Phoenix Mercury Season appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
The Phoenix Mercury turned some heads in 2024, clawing their way back into playoff relevance with a 19–21 record and a 7th seed finish, which more than doubled their win total from the year before. With Kahleah Copper leading the charge and Brittney Griner anchoring the paint, the Mercury showed flashes of their championship DNA, even as they bowed out in the first round to Minnesota. It was a season of grit, growth, and a glimpse at what could be.

This year, things are looking up, and the Mercury are striving for greatness. With Diana Taurasi retired and Griner now in Atlanta, the Mercury retooled in a big way. They brought in All-Stars Alyssa Thomas and Satou Sabally, added veteran guard Sami Whitcomb, and handed the keys to second-year head coach Nate Tibbetts. They now have a deeper, faster, more versatile squad that’s already making noise in 2025. Are we in for a surprise this year? They just may be my sleeper pick for the season.

What channels have Phoenix Mercury games?

The Phoenix Mercury will be showcased across a wide range of platforms throughout the 2025 season. According to their current schedule, most national broadcasts will air on ION and Amazon Prime Video, with additional games on NBA TV, ESPN3, CBS Sports Network, and ABC/ESPN+. Locally, fans in Arizona can tune in via Arizona’s Family (3TV, CBS 5) and Arizona’s Family Sports.

Pro tip: In-market fans can stream most Phoenix Mercury games live through Merc+, the team’s official platform now available on Roku, Apple TV, and Amazon Fire TV. Nationally televised games are excluded, but Merc+ offers full access to local broadcasts, preseason matchups, and exclusive behind-the-scenes content.

2025 Phoenix Mercury TV schedule

The 2025 season marks the 28th year for the Phoenix Mercury, one of the WNBA’s original franchises. With a passionate fan base and a long history of success, the Mercury are always a must-watch team.

This year, the team has taken a big step forward, finishing the regular season with a stellar 27–17 record. Now, as they head into the postseason, the big question is whether they can turn that regular-season success into something more. Scroll down for the full Mercury TV schedule, including tip-off times and broadcast details.

Best TV plans for watching the Phoenix Mercury

If you never want to miss a Mercury game, you’ll need a TV plan that covers you both locally and nationally.

WNBA League Pass is your go-to for replays and all out-of-market games. But since the Mercury are featured on a mix of national platforms, you’ll want a streaming service that carries those channels. Fubo checks most of those boxes, and even carries local channels for in-market fans. Though you’ll also need a separate Amazon Prime Video subscription to access the Mercury’s six Prime Video games this season.

Here are the details to help you choose the best TV service for following the WNBA.

Fubo ($14.99–$94.99/mo.)

Fubo is a solid pick for Phoenix Mercury fans who want both national and local coverage in one place. It offers access to major networks airing Mercury games in 2025, like ION, CBS Sports Network, NBA TV, and ABC, and you even get local Arizona stations such as 3TV and Arizona’s Family Sports, which carry in-market broadcasts.

One thing I’ll bring to your attention is that you may need the Fubo Extra or Elite package to unlock channels like NBA TV. But if you’re in the Phoenix area and want a one-stop streaming solution, Fubo covers a lot of ground.

WNBA LeaguePass ($12.99/mo.)

Since the WNBA season skips winter, you may be out living your best life during the warmer months. That means you’ll need a way to watch Mercury games on your own time, and WNBA League Pass is a smart backup. It’s built for fans who want flexibility, offering full replays and out-of-market games you can stream anytime.

Keep in mind that live games shown nationally (like those on ESPN, ION, and Prime Video) and locally may be blacked out due to broadcast rights. But the good news is that those matchups usually unlock for replay not long after the final buzzer.

Find the best service in your area

Enter your zip code below to see your area’s top TV providers.

How to watch the Phoenix Mercury for free

If you’re hoping to watch the Mercury without cracking open your wallet, your options are limited, but not nonexistent. A handful of nationally televised games (seven, to be exact) air for free on ION, so keep an “eye on” the schedule for those gems.

Also, WNBA League Pass occasionally tosses out free game previews during the season, which is nice if you’re out of market or just curious about the Mercury. And if you’re in Arizona, Arizona’s Family (3TV/CBS 5) will broadcast 36 Mercury games locally, no cable required, just a digital antenna and you’re good to go.

Amazon Prime Video also sometimes offers free trials, and they’ve got a few Mercury games on deck this season. So if you time it right, you might just sneak in a game or two on the house.

How to watch the Phoenix Mercury FAQ

How can I watch the Mercury if I live outside of Arizona?

Fans outside the Phoenix Mercury TV market can use WNBA League Pass to stream all the out-of-market games that aren’t on a national channel. A season-long subscription costs $34.99 and comes with on-demand replays of every WNBA game this season.

How can I stream Phoenix Mercury games?

You have several options for streaming the Mercury. Locally, Merc+ is a solid standalone option for in-market coverage. But nationally, you’ll want a live TV streaming service like DIRECTV, Fubo, or YouTube TV. You’ll also need an Amazon Prime Video subscription for its exclusive games.

What radio station is the Phoenix Mercury on?

Locally, you can listen to Phoenix Mercury coverage on Arizona Sports 98.7 FM. Live WNBA games also air nationwide on SiriusXM NBA Radio (ch. 86).

Have the Phoenix Mercury ever won a championship?

The Phoenix Mercury secured three WNBA championships in 2007, 2009, and 2014.

Who is #2 on the Phoenix Mercury?

Number two on the Phoenix Mercury is none other than the four-time all-star, 2021 Finals MVP, and versatile offensive threat that is Kahleah Copper. She started her career on the bench in 2016 with the Washington Mystics, but had a breakout performance in 2021, leading the Chicago Sky to their first-ever WNBA championship.

Why you should trust us

No one wants to do a ton of research in order to figure out where they can watch their favorite teams and players in action. But … we do! You can rest assured that our comprehensive guide covers all the most pertinent information related to watching the Phoenix Mercury in 2025, locally, nationally, and for free, when possible.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

item.title: NFL Schedule This Week: Your TV Guide to Every Week 5 Game
item.dc:creator: Taylor Kujawa
item.description:
Get ready for game day with our NFL TV schedule guide. We update this page weekly during the NFL regular season, so you can easily find kick-off times and channel listings for the week’s biggest matchups.

The post NFL Schedule This Week: Your TV Guide to Every Week 5 Game appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
October is here, which means it’s officially spooky season. But for me, the best part of fall isn’t just the candy corn and pumpkin patches; it’s that the NFL season is really starting to heat up. Speaking of spookiness, if you’re a horror movie fan, don’t forget to apply for our Halloween “Thrillternship” Dream Job before the October 7 deadline. One lucky applicant will get paid $666 to watch horror movies.

After a wild Week 4 that saw a 40–40 tie on Sunday night and the Chiefs’ offense finally come back to life, the league feels as unpredictable as ever. The biggest story for me was watching the Ravens’ championship hopes get decimated by injuries, while rookie QB Jaxson Dart led the Giants to a stunning upset win over the previously undefeated Chargers.

With four teams on a bye, this week’s NFL schedule is a bit lighter. But it’s still packed with high-stakes matchups, including three pretty solid primetime games. I’ve laid out the complete Week 5 TV schedule below, including kick-off times and channel listings.

Jump to:

  • CTV’s NFL Game of the Week
  • NFL TV schedule this week

Bookmark this page. Stay updated with the NFL schedule all season by saving this page to your web browser.

Find the best TV provider for football

Enter your zip code below to see the top-ranked TV providers available in your area.

CableTV.com’s NFL Game of the Week

San Francisco 49ers at Los Angeles Rams | Amazon Prime Video

Coverage begins Thursday, October 2, at 8:15 p.m. ET: The best game of Week 5 is the one that kicks it all off. This Thursday night showdown is a massive, early-season battle for first place in the NFC West between the 3–1 49ers and the 3–1 Rams. Los Angeles is rolling after a big win over the Colts, while the Niners are looking to prove last week’s loss was just a fluke.

I’ll be watching the chess match between Rams QB Matthew Stafford and the San Francisco defense. Stafford has been playing at an MVP level. He’s now facing a Niners defense that, since losing Nick Bosa for the season, has struggled to pressure the quarterback. On the other side, the Rams must find an answer for Christian McCaffrey, who has absolutely dominated them in recent matchups. The big X-factor is the health of 49ers QB Brock Purdy, who’s dealing with a good ole toe injury.

Overall, this matchup feels like a toss-up. But with Stafford playing at such a high level and the game being at home, I’m giving a slight edge to the Rams. Remember, this is the week’s Thursday Night Football matchup, which means it streams exclusively on Prime Video for most of the country. Local fans can also catch the game airing in Los Angeles on KTVU (FOX 2) and in the Bay Area on KTTV (FOX 11).

NFL Schedule This Week FAQ

What week is it in the NFL?

It’s currently Week 5 of the 2025 NFL regular season. This is a key week on the calendar, as it marks the first time teams will be on a bye.

Which NFL teams have a bye this week?

The four teams on a bye in Week 5 are the Atlanta Falcons, Chicago Bears, Green Bay Packers, and Pittsburgh Steelers.

Who is the best team in the NFL today?

After four weeks, the only two undefeated teams remaining are the Philadelphia Eagles and the Buffalo Bills, who are holding down the top two spots in the NFL Power Rankings. After their big Monday night win, the Detroit Lions have also solidified their place in the top three.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com Sports Editor, Taylor Kujawa, has been writing and refining this weekly NFL schedule guide since the 2022 season. Each week, he reviews the official league schedule and cross-references it with every broadcast partner. This process assures the channel listings for each matchup—including Spanish-language and alternate broadcasts—are always accurate.

Taylor’s “Game of the Week” selection comes from that hands-on experience, as he watches multiple games in their entirety every game week. His pick is a blend of on-field analysis (team performance, playoff stakes) and off-field expertise (broadcast accessibility). That dedicated, hands-on experience is what gives this TV guide a true fan’s perspective.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about CableTV.com and the methods we use.

item.title: How To Watch the 2025 Las Vegas Aces Season
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Finn
item.description:
Don’t miss a minute of Las Vegas Aces basketball this season. Get the complete 2025 TV schedule, channel listings, and how to watch every game.

The post How To Watch the 2025 Las Vegas Aces Season appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
The Las Vegas Aces entered 2025 with a chip on their shoulder after falling short of a three-peat last season. Despite a dominant regular season in 2024, they were dethroned in the semifinals by the New York Liberty, who went on to win their first-ever WNBA title.

Now, the Aces are navigating a season of challenges, as the team has taken a dip from last year. A losing record, combined with a lower offensive and defensive rating, has fans worried. But who doesn’t love a good comeback story?

This year, A’ja Wilson remains a force, averaging 21.5 points, 9.1 rebounds, and 2.4 blocks per game–but the supporting cast has shifted. Kelsey Plum is gone, Jewell Loyd is in, and injuries plus chemistry shakeups have tested the team’s depth. Still, there’s promise amongst Wilson’s leadership, Chelsea Gray’s steady playmaking, and a recent win over Golden State that hints at a team capable of turning the tide.

With national broadcasts and local coverage lined up, fans won’t want to miss watching what could be a gritty second-half resurgence.

What channels have Las Vegas Aces games?

The Las Vegas Aces may be in a transitional season, but their national visibility hasn’t dipped. In 2025, fans can watch Aces games across a jam-packed national TV lineup. ABC, ESPN, CBS, CBS Sports Network, ION, NBA TV, and Amazon Prime Video all feature Las Vegas matchups throughout the season.

Locally, Vegas 34 and KTNV-TV 13 (ABC) are your go-to stations in Southern Nevada, airing 33 games as part of a multi-year broadcast deal. For fans in the Vegas Valley, these channels are the perfect way to watch A’ja Wilson dominate the paint and follow every moment of the team’s championship journey. But out-of-market viewers will need WNBA League Pass to catch these broadcasts.

Want radio coverage? Las Vegas Aces games are broadcast locally on KWWN/ESPN Radio 1100 AM. Select matchups also air on FOX Sports Radio 98.9 FM / 1340 AM, giving fans reliable access to live play-by-play coverage.

2025 Las Vegas Aces TV schedule

After a stretch of uncharacteristic, inconsistent play to start the season, the Las Vegas Aces have put the league on notice. Since August 3, the team has been on an absolute tear, winning 16 straight games to close out the regular season. That difficult start is now officially in the rearview mirror.

With a ton of momentum on their side, the Aces are heading into the postseason looking like the championship contenders we all expected. Check out the complete 2025 Aces TV schedule below, featuring all game times and channel listings.

Best TV plans for watching the Las Vegas Aces

If you’re tuning in for the Aces’ 2025 season, YouTube TV is a fantastic choice because it bundles nearly every key channel. Its base plan includes ABC, ESPN, CBS, CBS Sports Network, ION, and NBA TV, so you’ll be covered for most national games. Still, you’ll need a separate Amazon Prime Video subscription to watch games exclusive to that service.

YouTube TV also includes Vegas 34 and KTNV, the local stations airing 33 Aces games, making it one of the few platforms that delivers both national and regional coverage in one package. If I were you, I’d pair it with WNBA League Pass so you can watch all out-of-market WNBA games and replays.

If you support the Aces from outside Nevada, keep in mind that blackouts may apply if you’re trying to stream games airing locally in Las Vegas. That’s where League Pass comes into play.

Which TV providers carry the Las Vegas Aces?

You can get courtside with the Aces through most TV providers, but that doesn’t guarantee you’ll catch all games. That part actually depends on your location and whether you’ve got Prime Video.

If you’re okay getting nearly every game besides those Amazon exclusives, you’re in good hands with YouTube TV and League Pass.

Here’s a breakdown I put together that lists popular TV providers and whether they carry the primary WNBA channels. Just make sure you don’t get caught sleeping and forget that you need that Prime Video subscription for some games.

How to watch the Las Vegas Aces for free

There really isn’t a way to watch every game in the W for free, but you do have some options.

Platforms like Prime Video offer a 30-day free trial, allowing you to sneak in some games for free. WNBA League Pass also has a trial period, but it’s just seven days. So, you’d have to set that up wisely to align with the games you want to watch if you weren’t trying to pay for the subscription.

You can watch 33 Las Vegas Aces games using an over-the-air (OTA) antenna if you live in Southern Nevada. These games are broadcast locally on Vegas 34 (KMCC) and KTNV-TV 13.

To see if an OTA antenna works for your location:

  • Use the FCC’s Reception Map Tool to check which channels you can receive.
  • Visit CableTV.com’s guide to the Best OTA Antennas for help choosing the right model.

We recommend the Mohu Leaf 50—a sleek indoor antenna with a 60-mile range that’s perfect for urban and suburban homes. It’s a one-time purchase that unlocks free access to dozens of Aces games, so no TV subscription required.

How to watch Las Vegas Aces FAQ

How can I watch the Aces if I live outside of Las Vegas?

The best way to watch the Aces from out-of-market is with a WNBA League Pass subscription. It’s a fantastic service that streams nearly every game that isn’t airing on a national or local channel in your area.

Who are the star players on the Las Vegas Aces?

All-Star A’ja Wilson, a dominant forward known for her scoring, rebounding, and shot-blocking. She’s joined by veterans like Chelsea Gray and Jackie Young, forming one of the most dynamic cores in the WNBA.

How many championships have the Aces won?

The Las Vegas Aces have won two WNBA titles in 2022 and 2023. They’ve consistently been a playoff powerhouse and are known for their high-octane offense and physical defense.

Why you should trust us

When you’re ready to watch your favorite team, no one wants to scour the web and compare everything side-by-side. You don’t want to have to go to a bunch of different sites to figure out the channels that carry WNBA games. And that’s where we come in.

At CableTV.com, we’ve spent hours combing through streaming platforms, broadcast schedules, and league blackout rules to create the ultimate guide for watching the Las Vegas Aces in 2025.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Game day starts here!

item.title: How To Watch the 2025 WNBA Playoffs
item.dc:creator: Eric Chiu
item.description:
Who will win it all in the WNBA this year? Get ready to watch the WNBA Playoffs when the postseason tips off this fall.

The post How To Watch the 2025 WNBA Playoffs appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
The 2025 WNBA Finals are set for a showdown between the Las Vegas Aces and the Phoenix Mercury, which starts on Friday, October 3. After all the excitement and surprises of the playoffs so far, I’m even more hyped than I was at the start.

If you haven’t been watching so far but want to find out how, I’ve got you covered. Keep reading to learn everything you need to know about watching the 2025 WNBA Playoffs on TV.

Jump to:

  • WNBA Playoffs channels
  • WNBA Playoffs TV schedule
  • Best WNBA Playoffs TV Plans
  • Watch WNBA Playoff games for free

Want more TV sports coverage?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest event-viewing guides, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

What channels are the WNBA Playoffs on?

The 2025 WNBA Playoffs will air exclusively across the ESPN family of networks: ABC, ESPN, and ESPN2. Select matches will also have Spanish-language coverage on ESPN Deportes.

Because all these channels are under the Disney umbrella, the viewing experience is refreshingly simple. I’ve outlined the entire playoff TV schedule in the next section, but if you’d rather get straight to the provider recommendations, you can jump down to my Best TV Plans.

Want radio coverage? You can listen to every WNBA playoff game on SiriusXM NBA Radio (ch. 86). Regional coverage will also air on the radio affiliates of each playoff team.

2025 WNBA Playoffs TV schedule

The road to the WNBA Finals is set. I’ve laid out the complete playoff TV schedule below, from the first-round matchups all the way through a potential Game 7 of the Finals. I’ll be keeping this guide updated with the latest start times and broadcast information as the postseason unfolds.

Game Date Time (ET) Channel
First Round (Best of 3)
Golden State Valkyries at Minnesota Lynx (Game 1) Sunday, Sept. 14 1:00 p.m. ESPN

Indiana Fever at Atlanta Dream (Game 3) Thursday, Sept. 18 9:30 p.m. ESPN2
New York Liberty at Phoenix Mercury (Game 3) Friday, Sept. 19 9:00 p.m. ESPN2
Semifinals (Best of 5)
Indiana Fever at Las Vegas Aces (Game 1) Sunday, Sept. 21 3:00 p.m. ABC
Phoenix Mercury at Minnesota Lynx (Game 1) Sunday, Sept. 21 5:00 p.m. ESPN

Game 3: Las Vegas Aces at Phoenix Mercury Wednesday, Oct. 8 8:00 p.m. ESPN
Game 4: Las Vegas Aces at Phoenix Mercury Friday, Oct. 10 8:00 p.m. ESPN
Game 5: Phoenix Mercury at Las Vegas Aces* Sunday, Oct. 12 3:00 p.m. ABC
Game 6: Las Vegas Aces at Phoenix Mercury* Wednesday, Oct. 15 8:00 p.m. ESPN
Game 7: Phoenix Mercury at Las Vegas Aces* Friday, Oct. 17 8:00 p.m. ESPN

Data effective as of post date.

*If necessary.

Best TV plans for the WNBA Playoffs

The WNBA Playoffs viewing experience will be remarkably uncomplicated this season, as it has been in seasons past. To help you find the ideal TV plan for the postseason, I’ve broken down my two top recommendations. One’s a great new standalone option for dedicated sports fans, while the other’s a fantastic live TV streaming service for those who want a more comprehensive package.

Best standalone option: ESPN Unlimited ($29.99/mo.)

ESPN recently released a direct-to-consumer service that houses all of its affiliated channels, including ESPN2, ESPN+, and several others. Because the WNBA Playoffs will appear on ABC and two ESPN networks, I recommend this service for fans who want to see all the action.

The ESPN Unlimited plan costs $29.99 per month. While that may seem pricey, it’s worth it because it’s a one-stop shop for much more than just the WNBA Playoffs. The service offers a wealth of additional fall sports, including several NBA and NFL games, a ton of college football, and a deep library of original programming and sports documentaries.

Best all-in-one package: YouTube TV ($82.99/mo.)

If you’re looking for a complete cable replacement that will have you set for the entire WNBA Playoffs and more, my top recommendation is YouTube TV. It includes ABC, ESPN, and ESPN2 in its base plan, along with over 100 other channels and unlimited DVR storage.

I’ve been using YouTube TV for a couple of WNBA seasons now, and I love it. On top of its robust channel lineup, you get a slick Multiview feature for watching up to four games at once. It’s the perfect setup, especially this time of year when all the major sports leagues start to overlap.

Looking for the most elite TV plan?

Visit our main How To Watch the WNBA page for additional tips on watching women’s pro basketball. You can also enter your zip code below to find the best TV providers in your area.

How to watch the WNBA Playoffs for free

While you can’t watch every WNBA Playoff game for free, you can still catch some of the biggest matchups without paying.

Your best truly free option is a digital antenna. Any playoff game that airs on ABC, including some WNBA Finals games, will be available to watch over the air at no cost. It’s a simple one-time purchase that pays off all postseason.

For the games on ESPN and ESPN2, your best strategy is to use a live TV streaming free trial. Services like Fubo and YouTube TV often offer trial periods, giving you short-term access. Just remember to time your sign-up around a big game and cancel before the trial ends.

Try Fubo for Free

How to watch the WNBA Playoffs FAQ

How do the WNBA Playoffs work?

The WNBA features an eight-team bracket with the league’s best teams based on their regular-season record. The first-round games are played on a best-of-three series, while the semifinal is a best-of-five. Starting in 2025, the WNBA Finals will be a best-of-seven series.

When do the WNBA Playoffs start?

The 2025 WNBA Playoffs start on Sunday, September 14.

Can I stream the WNBA Playoffs?

Yes. The best way to stream the WNBA Playoffs is by subscribing to the ESPN direct-to-consumer service. It's just $29.99 per month and includes ESPN's entire library of channels. Games on ABC will be simulcast on ESPN.

How can I watch the WNBA Playoffs if I live outside the US?

The best way to watch the WNBA Playoffs from outside the U.S. is with WNBA League Pass. The international version of the service typically streams all playoff games that are not subject to local blackouts in your specific country.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com senior writer, Eric Chiu, conducted thorough research on the WNBA postseason schedule, and put together a comprehensive list of matchups and channel listings. Utilizing that data, he compared popular TV providers to determine the most efficient way to watch the most games for hardcore and casual fans alike.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Game day starts here!

  • Best Streaming Services for Sports

item.content:encoded:
Get ready for the newest simulcast anime premieres

It’s time once again for our quarterly anime round-up. Let’s go over what you can expect from the top anime streaming services: Crunchyroll, Netflix, Hulu, and HIDIVE. Hulu will merge with Disney+ in 2026, so this may be your last chance to catch anime on its standalone platform!

This season’s anime simulcasts are organized by streaming service and then by air date. Click through the tabs to see details for each day of the week. If you’ve got a favorite anime streaming service, jump to its section using its logo below.

Don’t have a favorite anime streaming service yet? Our anime streaming guide has everything you need to know about the major contenders.

✦ Allow me to introduce myself! I’ve been CableTV.com’s resident anime expert for over three years. As part of the editorial staff, it’s my job to keep readers informed with all the latest in TV and streaming news. If you have a question about streaming services or animation, I’m your gal.

Bookmark this page and check back in January for our thoughts on the Winter 2026 season.

Mechanical Marie: This would be a nightmare scenario for me, but somehow Japan has turned it into a romantic comedy: Mechanical Marie is about a stoic woman who takes a job as a maid for a rich client. Let’s Play: When you’re a reviewer, you have to be careful what you say online. You never know when you could run into the people who make the things you put on blast. You might even move in next door to the person who made a video game you hated, and you might get pulled into an anime rom-com.

(I don’t think I’ll ever have a meet-cute with Mr. Netflix though, so I’m probably safe as a streaming reviewer.)

May I Ask for One More Thing?: I love otome isekai anime. I don’t care how many they make, I’m going to watch them all. This one isn’t even an isekai—the main character has no supernatural knowledge of the world she lives in, and probably has never played a video game in her life. But when faced with the cliche villainess rejection, she decides to throw hands. I’m so excited to watch this one, you guys.

One of the bigger selling points of streaming TV is that it’s usually less expensive than cable or satellite . . . OK, it’s the biggest selling point. We’re not cheap; we’re “dollar-conscious.”

But there’s always a new way to save a few bucks, even in the streamverse. We’ve done the research and found several sweet promos and deals for streaming TV services that you can take advantage of right now.

Everybody loves Disney+, the ($9.99–$15.99/mo.) streaming service that gives you access to a gazillion Disney movies and shows (and Baby Yoda and Loki), but what if that’s still not enough content for your eyeballs? Get this: you can bundle Disney+ with Hulu and ESPN+.

With the Disney Bundle Trio Basic, you can combine Disney+ Basic (regularly $9.99 a month) with Hulu (basic version with ads, regularly $9.99 a month) and ESPN+ (regularly $11.99 a month). That’s a $31.97 value for just $16.99 a month. You could upgrade your internet speed with the extra green. With all that streaming, you might need it.

There are several ways you can customize the Disney Bundle. If you’re not interested in ESPN+, you can get the Duo Basic, which only includes ad-supported versions of Hulu and Disney+, for $10.99 a month.

If you want to go all-out and do away with pesky ads, you can upgrade to Duo Premium, which bundles ad-free versions of Disney+ and Hulu for $19.99 a month. You can also add ad-supported ESPN+ to the bundle for a total of $26.99 a month. Unfortunately, you can’t bundle in an ad-free version of ESPN+.

There are also variations on this streaming bundle package that can save you money on ad-free Hulu or Hulu + Live TV—check out our Hulu Bundles guide for all the discount streaming deets.

What to look for in streaming TV packages and deals

Before you sign up for that deal, check into these details first:

How long the deal lasts

Once your deal’s time is up, you’ll be charged the regular rate for the service. The Disney+ bundle has no expiration date (yet), but some plans are limited time only—after which, you’ll be charged the normal price each month.

Hidden fees

Sometimes a provider will sneak in some extra fees that can eat into your overall savings. It’s a strain on the eyes, but always read the fine print before you sign up.

Current customer eligibility

Most of the deals we’ve covered here are aimed at new customers as an incentive to sign up, but current customers can sometimes get in on them too. If you’re a customer in good standing with your provider, contact customer service and simply ask if you can take advantage of the same offer as a new customer. In most cases, they’ll work with you to keep you as customer.

What are the best streaming TV deals?

The Disney+, Hulu, ESPN+ bundle is the deal to beat, in our opinion—mostly because, unlike most other offers, it doesn’t (yet) have an expiration date. We also like the free Apple TV+ with an Apple product purchase, even though Apple keeps threatening to shorten or end the deal.

More so than the others, Sling TV is always wheeling and dealing for customers—check out our Sling TV Deals guide.

Best streaming TV deals FAQ

Which streaming TV service is best?

The best streaming TV service for you depends on what you’re into. If you don’t care about sports or local channels, Philo is a good deal at $28.00/mo.. But, if you want more than 70+ channels and all the sports, YouTube TV or Sling TV might be the way to go. Read about all the major streaming services in our Best Live TV Streaming Services and Best On-Demand Streaming Services guides.

What is the cheapest streaming subscription?

The current cheapest live TV streaming service is Philo, and the cheapest on-demand streaming service is Discovery+. There are also several free streaming services out there, like Tubi and Pluto TV, and paid streaming services that allow anyone to watch select content for free, like Amazon Prime Video and Crunchyroll. Read about more free and moderately priced streamers in our Best Free and Cheap Streaming Services review.

Which streaming service is the best value?

At $81.99–$95.99/mo., we think that Hulu + Live TV is the best value you can get out of a live TV streaming service in 2025. Meanwhile, the Paramount+ with SHOWTIME bundle is our pick for the best value on-demand streaming service.

What is the best option to get all streaming services in one package?

If you want all of your streaming services to live in the same place, we recommend subscribing through a service like Amazon Prime Video or Hulu. If you want a formal streaming bundle package with discounts, check out the Disney Bundle. It doesn't include every service, but it'll get you Disney+ and Hulu, plus either ESPN+ or HBO Max. Then you can add additional services (Paramount+ Premium, Cinemax, and STARZ) onto your Hulu subscription. If Hulu doesn't offer all of the services you're after, you'll probably find what you want on Amazon Prime Video. Its catalog includes MGM+, Hallmark+, Crunchyroll, and more. Amazon also offers certain bundle discounts, like a monthly discount on STARZ and AMC+ subscriptions when purchased together.

Is there a Netflix bundle?

There is now a Netflix bundle. Verizon +Play will, for a limited time, offer Netflix & HBO Max (With Ads) in a bundle for $10 month with select mobile and home internet plans. This adds up to monthly savings of $7.98, which can add up quick as streaming prices rise.

Is there a bundle for multiple streaming services?

Yes, there are lots of streaming service bundles available in 2025. We recommend the Disney+ Bundle and Paramount+ Premium. For more deals, you can also check Amazon Prime Video to see which services it currently offers discounts on.

Why you should trust us

Our monthly promotions are tracked down by an engaged team of data specialists so that you get the most accurate information possible. We also put our editorial know-how to the test by comparing the deals and top packages from nationwide providers so you don’t have to. To learn more about our methods, check out our How We Rank page.

item.title: 31 Days of Halloween: The Ultimate Horror Streaming Guide
item.dc:creator: Randy Harward
item.description:
The nightmare of choice paralysis can waste a lot of your time as you decide what to watch in October. Knowing in advance what’s available to watch, and on which streaming services, helps. That’s a lot of research, though. Who has that kinda time? I do.

The post 31 Days of Halloween: The Ultimate Horror Streaming Guide appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
The word “Halloween” makes me drool, anticipating tasty treats and freaky flicks. As an adult with dental bills, dietary restrictions, and a societal expectation that I won’t trick-or-treat, I care more about the movies. I get to rescreen old favorites, experience new horror hotness, and watch my family and friends cower on the couch. So the concept of “31 Days of Halloween,” where you watch a creepshow a day throughout October, really appeals to me.

I know it’s not just me. Many of you, not just avid horror fans, get into the spooky cinema spirit at Halloween. But the nightmare of choice paralysis can waste a lot of your time as you decide what to watch in October. Knowing in advance what’s available to watch, and on which streaming services, helps. That’s a lot of research, though. Who has that kinda time? I do.

I spent most of September tracking the horror offerings of Hulu, HBO Max, Netflix, Paramount+, Peacock, Prime Video, Screambox, Shudder (and, by association, AMC+), and Tubi. Once I knew what’d be on each service in October, I compiled lists with a movie recommendation (or two) for all 31 days. You’ll find everything from certified horror classics to more contemporary creepshows, including the aforementioned horrific new hotness.
That’s 280+ recs across nine different streaming services you might already have—or are considering adding to your streaming stable. To that end, on each of the pages linked below, you’ll not only find a month’s worth of recommendations, but also tips about each streaming service’s horror offerings—how many horror titles it has, which franchises are exclusive to the service, and more.

Use the links below to see the menu of monstrous delights for your favorite streaming services. Enjoy your 31 days of Halloween!

Pro tip: Don’t forget to exploit take advantage of streaming service free trials—you might be able to get through your October horror binge without spending a dime.

item.title: 31 Days of Horror Movies on Shudder
item.dc:creator: Randy Harward
item.description:
It’s hard to beat Shudder. Curated by and for horror fans, the streaming service has 720+ horror films and 55+ horror series. It’s the largest horror-centric streaming library I’ve encountered, and so far the best.

The post 31 Days of Horror Movies on Shudder appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
When it comes to niche horror streaming services, it’s hard to beat Shudder. Curated by and for horror fans, the streaming service—which is celebrating its 10th anniversary this year—Shudder has 720+ horror films and 55+ horror series. It’s the largest horror-centric streaming library I’ve encountered, and so far the beast best. Shudder has:

  • Hundreds of Shudder Original and Exclusive movies
  • Streaming exclusivity for John Carpenter’s original Halloween (1978)
  • A killer blend of classic and modern horror
  • Home of the V/H/S series
  • Horror host Joe Bob Briggs’ The Last Drive-In
  • Live watch parties
  • Exceptional horror documentaries
  • The best queer horror library
  • The best Giallo selection

Like Screambox, Shudder has everything, from classics to new stuff. Shudder also has the best original content, and loads of it. Last time I counted (around a year ago), it had nearly 200 original movies. That’s why, on our list of recommended horror movies on Shudder, only eight films are not originals or exclusives.

Pro tip: AMC+ includes all of Shudder—plus AMC, Sundance Now, IFC Films Unlimited, and more—for around the same monthly price.

As for themed weekends among our recs, the first one’s all about stirring your brains on high speed, with weird horror with Flying Lotus’s Kuso, Phil Tippett’s Mad God, and Ryan Kruger’s Fried Barry. Themed weekend #2 is devoted to the sublimely disturbing V/H/S found-footage anthology series—starting with the brand-new V/H/S/Halloween.

For the third weekend, we have two Shudder originals—the new Night of the Reaper and the slightly older Caveat. And for weekend #4, I’m spotlighting the latest Joe Bob Brigg’s Halloween special along with two of the scariest Shudder originals: When Evil Lurks and Late Night with the Devil.

See below for my entire list of recommended horror movies on Shudder.

item.title: 31 Days of Horror Movies on Amazon Prime Video
item.dc:creator: Randy Harward
item.description:
Right now, there are nearly 700 horror movies on Amazon Prime Video (for subscribers, natch. That’s almost as many as Shudder, the top horror streaming service. You know what else?

The post 31 Days of Horror Movies on Amazon Prime Video appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Right now, there are nearly 700 horror movies on Amazon Prime Video (for subscribers, natch. That’s almost as many as Shudder, the top horror streaming service. You know what else? Prime Video also has close to 2,500 more horror movies to rent via video-on-demand (VOD), including some of the newest titles around, like the hottest horror movie of 2025, Weapons. Here’s what else Prime Video has goin’ for it in the horror department:

  • Tons of obscure horror movies
  • Almost any horror franchise is available on VOD

I’ve included three VOD recommendations among the 28 others that stream for free with a Prime Video subscription. Two of them—Zach Cregger’s Barbarian and Weapons—come early in the first themed weekend of the month. (Careful with Weapons, though: It’s like 20 bucks to rent right now.)

There are two other weekends, one devoted to a Leatherface double-feature (The Texas Chain Saw Massacre 50th Anniversary and The Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2) and the other to 1985 zombies with Day of the Dead (1985) and The Return of the Living Dead (1985). (I goofed and didn’t come up with a theme for the second week of the month.) And then, on Halloween, I suggest a Terrifier double-feature (which could easily become a triple-feature if you rent Terrifier 3 on VOD).

See below for the complete schedule of recommended horror movies on Prime Video.

item.title: 31 Days of Horror Movies on Hulu
item.dc:creator: Randy Harward
item.description:
Happy Huluween! There are 231 horror movies on Hulu, not to mention 67 horror and thriller series. That makes the streaming service a great choice for horror fans. Want more reasons? Well, Hulu also has:

The post 31 Days of Horror Movies on Hulu appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Happy Huluween! There are 231 horror movies on Hulu, not to mention 67 horror and thriller series. That makes the streaming service a grave great choice for horror fans. Want more reasons? Well, Hulu also has:

  • Tons of modern horror releases
  • Scores of Hulu Originals
  • Dozens of horror and thriller series
  • The entire Alien franchise, including the new series Alien vs. Earth
  • Some of Shudder’s best titles

With all that to draw from, it was easy to come up with 31 horror movies to watch on Hulu in October.

Your first ghoulish course is the cannibal date movie Fresh, followed by the positively crazy Cuckoo from last year. Then our first Hulu horror weekend has the PG-13 Stephen King tale The Boogeyman before we hit you with more cannibalism (the horror western Bone Tomahawk) and a seriously sick serial killer in The House That Jack Built.

The other three themed weekends include the first three Alien movies plus the Aliens vs. Earth series on the weekend of October 10; two super-scary films (South Korea’s The Wailing and Argentina’s When Evil Lurks), then a weekend of modern horror with another King joint (Osgood Perkins’ The Monkey and Damian McCarthy’s Oddity. And on October’s final Friday—Halloween—we have the found footage freakout Late Night with the Devil.

You can see the rest of our recommended horror movies on Hulu in the image below. Happy horror-flicking!
